Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 01:16PM - edited Sep 11, 2012 01:20PM by SimplyAudrey The test Shar1 referred to isn't mainstream yet...though I do not doubt at all we will see its role increasing in diagnostics for women with dense tissue.  Here's a link to one of the companies who makes the machines:  http://www.dilon.com/pages/bsgi___molecular_breast_imaging/34.php My fave radiologist and I discussed it.  It's rather cutting edge....insurance coverage issues exist (not in guidelines for screening yet), and looking in the state of Florida 5 sites had it and none were well known cancer or diagnostic centers.  I went with the MRI....... Whle MRI has false positive issues...this type of test may prove to decrease those and fall more into favor.
Posts.Title: Dense Breast Tissue Reminder Aug242007 Shar1

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 03:12AM SimplyAudrey wrote: Balance is right.  Medications are a tool.  Some use them as toys to get them to a state of mind (nothing to do with pain, anxiety, etc). Keep them as a tool.....be accountable to yourself (and your doc) for what you take.....but stay AHEAD of the pain.  Playing catch up can only lead us to places we don't need to go! (Medication Journals are good.......pain level, what you took, and your pain level afterwards - share that with your doc prescribing the meds) Spiritual condition.....keep that FIT!  Meditation, prayer, reaching out, staying away from HALT....... CRITICAL. Meetings?  If you can't get out, have some friends come over.  It's amazing what a little laughter can do for pain! BEST of LUCK, and a big HUG for you!
Posts.Title: Recovering Addicts? Experience strength and hope please... juneaubugg SherylB

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2012 04:54AM SimplyAudrey wrote: Pinkgirl......there are on-line meetings as well.  I have used thouse when I can't make a "live one".  If you can do computer chat, these meetings work.  Also folks hang on line to chat 24 7 so there's always someone to talk to.  Talk about anonymity!  LOL....but it works.  And you're not waking someone up...they're already awake like here! PM me if you'd like details. With Love and Faith, A

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2012 04:53PM SimplyAudrey wrote: Just checking in......surgery went fine.....fills are already done and we're looking at exchange in 3 to 4 weeks.  I only had 2 drains (there wasn't much of me to remove to begin with) By the grace of God my HP only LCIS and ALH was found.  I did lose my right nipple and a small bit of the left (a risk I was willing to take) so that's a later decision to make.  The areola tissue is fine so it's nipple reconstruction or remove the left one to be symmetrical.  Later stress. BORED.  It's 4 weeks now.  Time to get back to work!  Jumping through the hoops to get there. Hope all is well with you ladies!  All in the storm path stay safe!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Tomorrow and I'm a Wreck LeahLeah LeahLeah

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2012 09:23PM SimplyAudrey wrote: Chrystie, My mom died December 21st and I found a hard lump the very next day.  I had been living on 3 to 4 hours sleep and Dunkin Turbo Coffee........ but funny, I knew everything would be OK. They Mammo'd and saw nothing, but on ultrasound it was quite evident, but "not malignant looking"....so 5 months later a follow up ultrasound showed it still there, bigger, and worthy of biopsy.  A week later pathology came back as a benign myofibroblastoma that needed to come out.  During that procedure, they incidentally found LCIS. NOW, after visiting a medical oncologist for risk evaluation (no family HX of BC, mom died of lung cancer and grandmom of bladder ca)....NEW lump right under left nipple.  Diagnostic US this coming week and core biopsy to be scheduled if needed.  No lymph nodes felt on me either. We all freak out a little when we find something.....and 9 times out of 10 it's not cancer.  Breathe, pray, and believe that all is well, and all will be well no matter what. (I needed to hear that too!)  Attitude is everything. I am SO sorry for your losses.  I do know what you're going through in a way, although grief is a very individual and personal experience.  You'll be in my thoughts and prayers.  Audrey
Posts.Title: Diagnostic Mammogram Monday... Not Looking Good Crystie75 pamelahope

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 12:02PM SimplyAudrey wrote: Breast density will mask findings....benign or otherwise.  That's the cause of increase risk.  Something can BE there yet not be seen, especially when you have kevlar like me.  The greater the density the more that can be hidden. MRI showed MUCH more than mammo or US....and fortunately or unfortunately.....it wasn't false positive.  The study paid for itself. T-21 and counting.
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 08:08PM SimplyAudrey wrote: Saw a medical oncologist today to discuss - she found a new "lump" in my left breast.  MRI here we come. Probably not a game changer (she doesn't think it's serious), but I made a deal with myself if I needed another biopsy I am opting for a PBMX.  One day at a time.  One step at a time. ~sigh~
Posts.Title: Dense breasts, LCIS, no kids.........Where to go from here? SimplyAudrey Needinfo

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2012 05:59AM - edited Aug 22, 2012 06:00AM by SimplyAudrey My breast tissue was described as "kevlar" (>90% density) FINALLY this past May.  Confirmed when having a biopsy of a 3 cm lump that was NOT seen on mammogram.....the doctor had a hard time passing the needle to the lump to get samples. Density is a relatively recent addition to breast cancer risk - the biggest thing is it HIDES issues.  After they excised the tumor they found, I did have an MRI that lit up....... I am grateful only LCIS was found after another biopsy, confirming an "incidental finding" at my excision biopsy.  Without that doctor (and finding the palpable lump myself) I probably would still be getting those "congrats!  Your mammogram revealed no issues!" cards in the mail.
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 08:56AM SimplyAudrey wrote: If you are anxed about the procedure and have the chance for a prescription, take it! I also recommend to ANYONE undergoing needle or wire localization prior to excision to SPEAK UP to the surgeon and anesthesiologist about your anxiety!  It's not like you are going to be operating heavy machinery anytime soon! :)
Posts.Title: Valium for biopsy? juliejk thatsvanity

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 12:51PM SimplyAudrey wrote: tlm.... The MRI showed an enhancement.  Later biopsy of that enhancement showed more of what was found during an excisional biopsy 3 months before (accidentally found).  MRI's often show enhancements that are really nothing, leading to unnecessary biopsies.  That's one of the controversies of them.  But they are VERY sensitive for showing problems.  My biopsy was positive for a problem found.  None of this was seen on mammogram OR ultrasound. T-21 means I have surgery in 3 weeks.  BMX with TE placement.
Posts.Title: Dense breasts - should I be worried? tlm1 farmerlucy

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2012 08:14AM SimplyAudrey wrote: Length, heighth, then depth.  Heterogenous density means "sporadically dense"....dense breast tissue interspersed with breast tissue that is less dense.  Unlike me......solidly dense and equated to kevlar. Hope that helps!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 11:08AM - edited Aug 20, 2012 11:08AM by SimplyAudrey Two biopsies for me, and pain after both.  For some reason I believe it's that dang titanium localization clip they insert after the biopsy. When I had the excision after the first biopsy and the benign tumor and clip were removed, no more pain.  Now, after second biopsy, discomfort is back at the biopsy site.  Go figure. BMX set for 10/1.  Hopefully I won't have to worry after that.
